content: The Act may be cited as the "Star-Spangled Banner and War of 1812 Bicentennial Commission Act". Congress finds that the War of 1812 was a crucial test for the United States Constitution and democracy, impacting regions like the Chesapeake Bay and the Great Lakes. Francis Scott Key's poem at the Battle of Baltimore led to the establishment of the American flag as an icon and the national anthem in 1932. The Act aims to establish the Star-Spangled Banner and War of 1812 Commemoration Commission to maximize public understanding of the War of 1812 in the history of the United States. It also seeks to ensure a national observance of the War of 1812, encourage excellent visitor experiences at War of 1812 sites, and facilitate international involvement in the observances. The Act establishes the Star-Spangled Banner and War of 1812 Commemoration Commission to promote public understanding of the War of 1812 in the US history. It aims to support marketing efforts for commemorative items, facilitate international involvement in observances, and promote the protection of War of 1812 resources for heritage tourism and economic benefits. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "commemoration" refers to the War of 1812, "Commission" refers to the Star-Spangled Banner and War of 1812 Bicentennial Commission, "qualified citizen" is a US citizen with interest and expertise in the commemoration, "Secretary" is the Secretary of the Interior, and "States" include various states in the US. The "Star-Spangled Banner and War of 1812 Bicentennial Commission" is established with 42 members, including citizens appointed by the Secretary and employees of the National Park Service. The "Star-Spangled Banner and War of 1812 Bicentennial Commission" consists of 42 members, including employees of the National Park Service and citizens appointed by the Secretary based on recommendations from Senate and House leaders. The "Star-Spangled Banner and War of 1812 Bicentennial Commission" consists of 42 members, including individuals with expertise in the history of the War of 1812 appointed by the Secretary. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies do not affect its powers, and voting requires an affirmative majority. The Commission consists of 42 members with expertise in the history of the War of 1812. A majority of members form a quorum. The Commission selects a chairperson and vice chairperson from its members. The vice chairperson acts as chairperson in the absence of the chairperson. The Commission must hold an initial meeting within 60 days of all members being appointed and meet at least twice a year. SEC. 5. DUTIES. The Commission's duties include planning, coordinating, and facilitating programs commemorating the events of the War of 1812, encouraging participation from various organizations to expand understanding and appreciation. They also provide technical assistance to States and localities. The Commission's duties include providing technical assistance, coordinating scholarly research, developing traveling exhibits, ensuring a lasting legacy, and reviewing essential facilities for the War of 1812 commemorations. The Commission for the War of 1812 sites is tasked with examining infrastructure, preparing strategic and annual plans, and submitting reports to Congress on gifts received. The Commission for the War of 1812 sites is responsible for examining infrastructure, preparing plans, and reporting to Congress on gifts received. The report includes a summary of the Commission's activities, a final accounting of funds received and expended, and the disposition of historically significant items and other properties. SEC. 6. POWERS. The Commission has the authority to solicit, accept, and use gifts, appoint advisory committees, authorize members to take actions, use the United States mails, and make grants for the commemoration. The Commission for the commemoration has the authority to procure supplies, services, and property, make legal agreements, and secure necessary information from Federal agencies. The Commission members serve without compensation, except for federal employees who receive their regular compensation. They are allowed travel expenses while performing Commission duties. Staff details are also outlined. The Chairperson of the Commission has the authority to appoint an executive director and additional staff without following civil service laws. The executive director's employment is subject to confirmation by the Commission, and the Chairperson can set their compensation without restrictions. The Commission's executive director and personnel pay rates are governed by specific regulations. Federal agencies can detail their personnel to assist the Commission as needed. The Commission may accept personnel from States and use voluntary services. The Director of the National Park Service will provide support services to the Commission. Service shall provide administrative support services to the Commission on a reimbursable basis. The Chairperson of the Commission may procure temporary and intermittent services. The Federal Advisory Committee Act does not apply to the Commission. This section does not supersede the authority of the States or the National Park Service concerning commemoration. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal years 2006 through 2015 is provided. The Commission will terminate on December 31, 2015, and all related materials will be transferred to Fort McHenry National Monument. Any remaining funds will be deposited in the Treasury's general fund. Passed the Senate December 16, 2005.
